LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY
Borrower Republic of Tajikistan
Project Description The Project will reduce poverty by improving power supply to
poor  communities  by  rehabilitating  and  reinforcing  power
transmission  and  distribution  facilities  in  the  war-damaged
areas in Khatlon and Dushanbe regions, and rehabilitating the
Nurek  Hydropower  Plant  (NHPP)  and  Central  Hydropower
Plant (CHPP).
Classification Primary Objective: Poverty Reduction. About 79 percent of
beneficiaries  live  below  the  poverty  line.  Based  on  the
classification  criteria  applicable  in  2001,  the  Project  would
qualify as a core poverty intervention.
Environment Assessment Category  B:  An  initial  environmental  examination  was
undertaken; the summary is a core appendix.
Rationale The power sector in Tajikistan has been severely affected by
the disintegration of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in
1990.  Construction  of  new  hydropower  plants  has  been
halted,  and  maintenance  of  the  existing  infrastructure  has
been neglected due to lack of funds.  As a result of the poor
economic situation of the country and damage caused by the
civil war, power supply is on the verge of collapse. In addition,
with  the  increase  in  prices  of  gas  and  petroleum  imports,
residential consumers have switched to electricity, generated
by hydropower plants. This has placed additional demand on
the generation facilities. Power cuts are common throughout
the year, especially during winter when insufficient electricity
is provided in rural areas. Without improvements in power
supply,  the  living  conditions,  particularly  of  the  poor,  will
continue to be miserable. Social surveys during the feasibility
study for the Project confirmed that the poor have significantly
less  access  to  electricity  supply  than  other  sectors  of  the
population. Given the urgent need to overcome power supply
constraints and to increase the efficiency of energy supply and
use,  top  priority  is  being  given  in  the  medium  term  to
retrofitting  and  rehabilitating  existing  power  facilities  rather
than  adding  new  capacity.  Such  measures  will  particularly
benefit the poor who cannot afford alternative fuels.
Objectives The Project will (i) improve people's quality of life and support
poverty  reduction  in  the  project  areas  by  increasing  the
availability  of  electricity;  and  (ii)  assist  in  the  postconflict
recovery of Tajikistan's economy. This will be achieved by
increasing the availability and reliability of power supply in an
environment-friendly  manner,  through  the  rehabilitation  of
existing generation, transmission, and distribution facilities.

ii
Scope Part A: rehabilitation and power supply improvement in poor  war-
damaged areas of Khatlon Region, consisting of rehabilitating CHPP,
strengthening transmission and distribution networks, installing consumer
meters, and providing electricity to about 24,000 mostly poor households.
Part B: rehabilitation of NHPP and associated transmission
facilities to improve reliability of power supply from this most
important power plant in Tajikistan.
Part C: rehabilitation of two major distribution substations in
Dushanbe  region  to  improve  reliability  of  power  supply  to
about 148,000 mostly poor households.
Part D: improvement of bulk metering for import and export of electricity
from and to the Kyrgyz Republic and Uzbekistan, and for power exchange
among regional distribution networks.
Part E: consulting services to support project implementation,
audit corporate and project accounts of Barki Tajik for fiscal
years 2000 and 2001, and develop implementing regulations
for the Energy Law.

million equivalent.

I.  THE PROPOSAL
1. I submit for your approval the following Report and Recommendation on a proposed
loan  to  the  Republic  of  Tajikistan  for  the  Power  Rehabilitation  Project.  The  Report  also
describes  two  technical  assistance  (TA)  grants  for  (i)  Improving  Barki  Tajik's  Billing  and
Collection System, and (ii) Introducing International Accounting Standards (IAS) at Barki Tajik,
and if the Board approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by
the Board, will approve the TAs.
II.  INTRODUCTION
2. Tajikistan ranks among the poorest countries in the world and is the poorest of the
former Soviet Union (FSU) economies, with a per capita gross domestic product (GDP) in 1997
of $178. In terms of the United Nations Development Programme’s human development index,1
in 1999 Tajikistan ranked 108 of 174 countries surveyed. Of the population, 83 percent live
below the poverty line and 33 percent live in absolute poverty. Six years of civil conflict and
natural disasters have severely damaged the infrastructure in the energy sector, particularly in
rural areas. In addition, the conflict has resulted in resources being diverted from much needed
rehabilitation. In the face of the energy crisis,2 the Government has taken initial measures to
reform the energy sector. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been supporting these
reforms through a program loan accompanied by TA.3
3. In  1998,  the  Government  requested  ADB’s  financial  assistance  to  rehabilitate  and
strengthen critical generation, transmission, and distribution systems of Barki Tajik, the state-
owned power company. In response, ADB provided TA4 in 1999 to examine the feasibility of
investment programs as the basis of a project that could be supported by ADB. Following
completion  of  the  project  preparation  studies  including  a  priority  plan  for  rehabilitating  the
generation, transmission, and distribution systems, the Appraisal Mission5 visited Tajikistan in
August 2000 to discuss the Project with the Government and Barki Tajik. The primary objective
of the Project is poverty reduction through (i) improving reliability of power supply throughout the
year; (ii) improving the quality of life of poor rural communities by making electricity available for
heating, lighting, and cooking; (iii) improving health and education facilities by making electricity
available for heating, lighting, and refrigeration; (iv) facilitating the creation of income generating
opportunities for small private enterprises and agriculture by improving irrigation; (v) saving time
for poor rural households who must search for alternative fuels;6 and (vi) introducing sector
reforms to ensure increased access to affordable electricity for the poor. About 79 percent of the
beneficiaries are expected to be the poor living below the poverty line. The Project framework is
in Appendix 1.

III. BACKGROUND
4. The dissolution of the FSU and the subsequent civil war in Tajikistan have had severe
social and economic consequences for the country in general, and for the project area of
Khatlon Region in the south in particular. The war, the general economic crisis, and the loss of
social services have caused a drastic deterioration in the living conditions of most of the
population. GDP contracted by about 60 percent in the six years following independence in
1991. Unemployment, virtually nonexistent before independence, increased to an estimated
30 percent in 1999.7 Thirty-three percent of the population live in absolute poverty, based on a
monthly per capita income of TJR10,000 ($5.9). The average per capita monthly income of
TJR12,3908 ($7.3) buys less than half of the minimum consumption basket. As a consequence,
the human development index for Tajikistan, estimated by the United Nations Development
Programme (UNDP), fell from 0.63 in 1991 to 0.54 in 1998.9 The Government places a high
priority on poverty reduction as demonstrated by its policy on social expenditures and by
drafting a national poverty reduction strategy (para. 23).
5. Khatlon Region is the poorest area of the country. Its poverty rate of 96 percent exceeds
the national average10 (Table 1). Khatlon was the site of the worst fighting and devastation of
the civil war. Beyond the terrible loss of life and human suffering caused by the war,11 much of
the infrastructure, private homes, and other property were destroyed or severely damaged.

6. The civil war and the economic crisis caused tax revenues to decline. As a result, the
Government’s ability to maintain basic infrastructure, including that of the energy sector, was
severely strained. Due to the poor condition of the existing infrastructure, power outages are
common. This affects agricultural, commercial, and industrial consumers, which leads to lower
production, higher production costs, and loss of income.
7. In  winter,  when  energy  supply  is  crucial,  most  rural  villages  have  insufficient  and
unreliable electricity supply. Major towns fare somewhat better, but daily outages of 3-6 hours
are common especially in winter. The poor quality of electricity supply in turn reduces the quality
of life of residential consumers. The restricted supply limits basic necessities like cooking and
heating  in  winter  and  constrains  the  Government’s  ability  to  provide  health,  social,  and
educational  services  in  rural  areas.  Hence,  improving  electricity  supply  services  will  have
positive effects on the health and nutrition of the poor in the project areas, which will in turn

8. Although the poverty rate in the region around the capital, Dushanbe, is below the
national average, it is a high 72 percent.12 The Dushanbe region could be Tajikistan’s primary

A.  The Energy Sector
1.  Overview
9. In Tajikistan, hydropower supplies 90 percent of energy produced and, hence, plays an
important role in the economy. The potential for hydropower is estimated at 527 terawatt hours
(TWh), of which only about 19 TWh (4 percent) is utilized. The extensive mountain ranges, such
as the Pamir and Fan mountains, which are among the highest in the world, have a layer of
glaciers that melts in the summer, resulting in extensive flow of water. During 1995 to 1998 this
produced on average an electric power surplus of about 4.2 TWh in summer, which used to be
exported mostly to Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. In winter, there was on average
a net deficit of about 1.0 TWh for the same period, which was met by imports from Kyrgyz
Republic, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan.
10. Because of the seasonal nature of hydropower resources, the country depends on
imported oil, gas, and coal to meet its energy requirements. In 1999, energy imports totaled
$103 million while exports (primarily electricity) amounted to $17.5 million. Net energy imports
are expected to increase as the domestic demand for imported fuels rises with the acceleration
of economic recovery. Prospects for increasing electricity exports are limited in the short to
medium  term  because  of  the  decline  in  electricity  demand  in  the  neighboring  countries.
Measures to promote efficient use of electricity and to increase domestic oil, gas, and coal
production are vital to improving the country’s overall balance of payments.
11. The country’s future energy production and trade will depend on a number of factors,
including (i) the rate of economic recovery of Tajikistan and the neighboring countries; (ii) the
trading arrangements negotiated with the neighboring countries; and (iii) the country’s ability to
attract private sector financing to develop domestic coal, oil, natural gas, and hydroelectric
power  resources.  Regional  energy  trade  will  continue  to  be  important  for  Tajikistan,  and
negotiated long-term contracts for power exports on equitable terms are a high priority for the
Government.
2.  Energy Supply and Demand
12. At the beginning of the 1990s, about two-thirds of Tajikistan's primary energy supplies
came from imports, mainly petroleum products and natural gas from Uzbekistan. In 1991, net
imports amounted to 1.58 million tons of petroleum products, 1.76 billion cubic meters of natural

activity due to the civil war and import price increases to international levels, net imports of
primary energy had fallen sharply to around one third of total supplies. In 1999, Tajikistan had
net imports of 300,000 tons of petroleum products and 0.4 billion cubic meters of natural gas,
and net exports of 0.18 TWh of electricity.13
13. Between 1991 and 1999, domestic energy consumption fell from about 7.8 million tons
of oil equivalent (toe) to about 3.0 million toe. The economic slowdown also caused a change in
the consumption pattern. In 1991, residential consumers accounted for 29 percent, industry for
40 percent, water supply and agriculture for 19 percent, and others for 12 percent. In 1999,
residential energy consumption increased to 36 percent, while industrial consumption remained
at 40 percent, water supply and agriculture dropped slightly to 17 percent, and others dropped
to 7 percent. In 1999, the per capita domestic energy consumption was about 0.5 toe. This was
about  20  percent  higher  than  the  average  for  ADB’s  developing  member  countries,  partly
because of the relatively low end-use efficiency and high heating requirements during winter.
With the rise in prices of imported fuel toward international levels during the past few years,
households switched to electricity, generated mainly by hydropower plants, for heating and
cooking. This partly accounts for the decrease of coal consumption from 690,000 tons in 1991
to 16,000 tons in 1999; and that of petroleum products from 1.68 million tons to 323,000 tons.
14. After a substantial decrease in electricity consumption due mainly to the effect of the civil
war and the related drop in industrial production, electricity consumption in Tajikistan has begun
to rise again, by 24 percent in 1998 and 6.5 percent in 1999. Despite this, the 1999 sales of
13.3  TWh  of  electricity  sales  were  still  significantly  below  the  levels  in  the  early  1990s
(18.0 TWh). Future demand growth will depend on industrial and agricultural production. GDP is
estimated to have grown by 3.7 percent in 1999, and is expected to grow further at 5.0 percent
per year in 2000 and 2001, and 6.0 percent in 2002.14 The expansion of the economy will put
upward pressure on power demand.
3.  Power System
15. Tajikistan’s power system comprises three separate power grids, the north, south, and
Gorno-Badakhshan systems, which are operated by Barki Tajik (Map). The installed capacity
totals  4,354  megawatts  (MW),  including  4,000  MW  of  hydropower  capacity.15  The  annual
average power generation of the hydropower plants is about 15.0 TWh. Although part of the
northwestern Gorno-Badakhshan system is connected to the south system around Dushanbe
through 110 kilovolt (kV) and 35 kV transmission lines, it is considered separate from an
operational  point  of  view.  The  northern  region  is  the  most  industrially  developed  part  of
Tajikistan but has only one hydropower plant, Kairrakumskaya (126 MW). This plant on the Syr
Darya (river) operates for irrigation in summer to meet the agriculture demands of Kazakhstan,
Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan, and generates limited power during winter. Therefore, Tajikistan
purchases power from Kyrgyz Republic, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan to meet the power
deficit. The north system is not connected directly to the main grid in the south but through the
Uzbekistan  power  network,  which  results  in  expensive  wheeling  charges  and  significant
technical losses. North Tajikistan therefore suffers from acute power deficits and depends on
power supply from Uzbekistan. To reduce Tajikistan's reliance on such arrangements, a north-
south connection would be ideal, but the high mountain ranges make its construction difficult
and expensive.

16. All major hydropower plants in the south are on the Vaksh River. NHPP with 3,000 MW
of installed capacity is the largest in Central Asia and generates electricity throughout the year.
It was constructed in stages from 1962 to 1979, and regulates the Vaksh River flow for irrigation
needs in the Amu Darya basin countries (Turkmenistan and Uzbekistan) during the growing
season  (May  to  July).  Baipinskaya  hydropower  plant  supplies  600  MW  and  has  been  in
operation since 1985. The Vaksh cascade, with 3 hydropower plants (including CHPP), provides
285 MW and has been in operation since the early 1960s. The Varzob cascade with three small
hydropower plants provides 25 MW in total and was built during 1932-1952.
17. Tajikistan has only two combined heat and power plants, with a total installed capacity of
346 MW. Both are in the south system. One, at Yavan, was closed in 1997 while the second, at
Dushanbe, operates only in winter, mainly to supply district heating to the city.
18. The Gorno-Badakhshan power system is much less developed than the north and south
systems. It covers the eastern mountainous part of Tajikistan (comprising about 46 percent of
the country’s territory), serves 216,000 people, and consists of several isolated network systems
and small and mini-hydropower plants with total installed capacity of about 30 MW. The largest
hydropower plants are Pamir 1 (14 MW) and Khorog (7 MW).
19. Prior to the break-up of the FSU, Tajikistan’s power system was operated as part of the
electricity pool of Central Asia,16 and was instrumental in providing peak capacity and reserve to
regulate  voltage  and  frequency  in  the  region.  Tajikistan  supplied  the  region  with  low  cost
hydroelectric power and received imports of oil and gas through net resource transfers. The
changes in trading relations and energy supply requirements among the neighboring countries
after their independence have complicated their energy sector operations. Hence, Tajikistan,
which used to generate about 4.2 TWh of excess electric power during the summer, is usually
not able to export all its surplus power to offset imports during the winter period. Therefore, ADB

20. Tajikistan has 4,268 kilometers (km) of power transmission lines, comprising 226 km of

rotational basis for urban and rural households, particularly during winter, due to nonavailability

and funds for maintenance, power cuts are becoming more frequent.

B.  Government Plans and Policies
23. The Government places a high priority on poverty reduction as demonstrated by (i) its
policy of maintaining social expenditures at 22 percent of the Government budget, (ii) launching
the drafting of a poverty reduction strategy paper (PRSP) with the World Bank and IMF in March
2000, and (iii) holding a seminar in May 2000 to discuss the results of the World Bank’s poverty
assessment study. By Presidential Decree of 24 March 2000, a special working group was
created to begin work on the PRSP, which eventually will be the national poverty reduction
strategy. This working group includes leading Tajik academics and deputy ministers, and is
scheduled to complete its assignment in the first half of 2001. The Government has requested
ADB to collaborate in this effort by carrying out additional focused poverty studies, providing
inputs into the final PRSP, and assisting the Government to develop a poverty monitoring
mechanism.
24. The  Government  recognizes  the  need  to  expand  and  diversify  Tajikistan’s  energy
system to supply reliable, efficient, and affordable energy to more people, support poverty
reduction, improve the standard of living, and bring economic development to rural areas. To
that end, the Government has adopted a strategy addressing policy and institutional reforms,
and rehabilitating and adequately maintaining the existing power systems. The sector policies
are designed to (i) facilitate the development of a legal and regulatory framework for efficient
operations (by 2002), (ii) increase the level of electricity tariffs toward full cost recovery (by
2004), (iii) encourage private sector participation in the generation and supply of power (by
enacting the Energy Law in October 2000), and (iv) promote energy conservation (by 2001).
25. A sound policy and regulatory framework is a prerequisite for more efficient public sector
operations and greater private sector participation in energy production and delivery services.
The Government recognizes the need to limit its involvement to policy and regulatory activities.
Responsibility for energy policy, planning, and oversight of energy enterprises is to be assumed
by the proposed MOE, which is to be staffed with an adequate number of qualified personnel.
C.  External Assistance to the Sector
26. External assistance to the energy sector has been limited. The World Bank’s Post
Conflict Emergency Reconstruction Project, which was approved in 1998, allocated $1.9 million
for rehabilitation of damaged energy infrastructure, and the European Union provided in 1998 a
TA to help develop the energy sector strategy and undertake feasibility studies on bankable
energy projects. In addition, the Aga Khan Foundation extended in 1996 financial assistance of
$12 million for completion of the Pamir I and II hydropower plants. In March 2000, the Aga Khan
Foundation, International Finance Corporation, and Government reached a general agreement
to establish a privately owned company that will operate the 14 MW Pamir II hydropower plant
and the electrical system in Gorno-Badakhsan Region. The company will be granted a 15-year
concession and will have a high degree of autonomy. The Swiss Agency for Development and
Cooperation has supported the Aga Khan Foundation with funding for 9 micro-hydroelectric

8
projects in Gorno-Badakhshan Region. The United Nations Office for Project Services has
implemented  13  micro  projects  involving  rehabilitation  of  war-damaged  property  and
infrastructure in Khatlon Region for a budget of $0.2 million. In late 1999, the Kuwait Fund
approved a TA grant of $0.4 million to examine the rehabilitation of the power distribution
system in Dushanbe, and will follow up with a distribution rehabilitation project for Dushanbe in
2002 for $15 million.
27. ADB  has  been  coordinating  its  operations  in  Tajikistan’s  energy  sector  with  other
agencies, particularly the World Bank and IMF. ADB's PCIPL and IMF's Poverty Reduction
Growth Facility have common conditionalities to the Government and Barki Tajik, and the
proposed Project incorporates similar or updated conditions.
D. Lessons Learned
28. ADB’s experience in the energy sector in Tajikistan is limited. With regard to policy
aspects, under the PCIPL it was noted that restructuring of the energy sector in transition
economies requires considerable time and effort and that some policy reforms under the PCIPL
had unrealistic targets and time frames. The proposed Project will be the first loan project in the
power sector,  but it draws on ADB's  experience in providing  rehabilitation  assistance  to other
countries in transition such as the Kyrgyz Republic20 and Mongolia.21 The major lessons learned
about project planning and implementation in such countries include (i) the need for human
resource development, capacity building, and training; (ii) the shortage of counterpart financing;
and (iii) the lack of familiarity with the policies and practices of multilateral financing agencies. In
particular, ADB experience has shown that it takes considerable time and effort to restructure,
corporatize and commercialize, and achieve full cost recovery in an economy that is undergoing
transformation.  ADB  projects  have  had  front-end  delays  in  implementation  due  to  the
governments' unfamiliarity with ADB procedures. Human resource development, assistance with
establishing the legal framework for restructuring, setting realistic targets for cost recovery and
financial performance, and familiarization with procurement and disbursement policies of ADB
and cofinanciers will therefore be an integral part of the Project. To overcome local counterpart
funding constraints, policy dialogue is focused on improving Barki Tajik’s financial situation.
E. ADB’s Sectoral Strategy
29. ADB’s interim operational strategy (IOS) for Tajikistan was approved by ADB's Board of
Directors in October 1998.22 Facilitating the transition to a market economy is the principal
objective of the strategy. In the near term, this objective will entail (i) supporting macroeconomic
and  sectoral  policy  reforms,  (ii)  facilitating  the  country’s  transition  to  a  market  economy,
(iii)  assisting  in  Tajikistan’s  postconflict  rehabilitation  and  reconstruction  efforts,  and
(iv) supporting natural disaster rehabilitation. ADB’s assistance will be provided to support policy
reforms, institution building, and investment operations.
30. Because of ADB’s comparative advantage at the sector level, the objectives of
the IOS will be achieved through sector operations. Given ADB’s resource constraints, the IOS
and  ADB’s  country  assistance  program  focus  on  a  few  priority  sectors  to  maximize  the
development impact. In view of the Government’s development priorities and the activities of

F.  Policy Dialogue
32. ADB's policy dialogue with the Government has focused on strengthening the ongoing
policy  reform  initiatives,  defining  further  areas  of  institutional  reform,  and  assisting
implementation  of  reforms.  These  include  market-oriented  policy  and  regulatory  reforms,
institutional strengthening of Barki Tajik, and measures to reach full cost recovery and financial
sustainability of Barki Tajik.
1. Policy and Regulatory Framework
33. The  Government’s  regulatory  role  in  the  energy  sector  is  essentially  limited  to  the
determination of tariffs and technical matters. Recognizing the important role of the energy
sector in the economic recovery, the Government expects the sector to become increasingly
self-financing,  thus  reducing  demands  on  the  national  budget.  However,  this  needs  to  be
matched by a strengthened role of the Government in sector regulation. In its efforts to develop
a clear and well-defined policy and legal framework, the Government issued the Energy Sector
Policy Statement (ESPS) in 1998 emphasizing its commitment to market-based reforms through
explicit policies and guidelines for defining its function as regulator. The ESPS envisaged
restructuring the energy sector to (i) increase the role of the private sector in providing services,
(ii) improve management efficiency and cost recovery of enterprises that remain under state
control, and (iii) allow market-based pricing. Under the policy reform agenda of PCIPL, the
Government was to enact an energy law that would restructure the energy sector, introduce
market-oriented  reforms,  reduce  its  involvement  as  an  investor  in  the  sector,  enhance  its
regulatory  functions,  facilitate  private  sector  involvement  in  developing  domestic  energy
resources, and unify the energy subsectors to improve management efficiency by establishing
the  MOE.  The  Government  was  to  have  made  substantial  progress  in  these  reforms  by
December 1999 but actual progress has been much slower because of the difficult economic
situation, political developments, national elections between November 1999 and March 2000,

10
and  the  rather  ambitious  targets  and  time  frame  envisaged  for  the  reform  agenda.  The
Government nevertheless remains committed to carry out the reform agenda. To enable this,
the  time  period  for  various  actions  under  the  PCIPL-supported  reform  agenda  has  been
extended by adopting the Energy Sector Action Plan (ESAP, Appendix 2) formulated with ADB
assistance. In accordance with the ESAP, the Energy Law was enacted in October 2000 and
the MOE will be fully established by December 2000.23 Other actions such as developing
charters and implementing regulations for the Energy Law are expected to follow with help from
consultants to be financed under the proposed loan.
2.  Governance Reforms
34. The ESPS emphasizes the importance of facilitating privatization of energy enterprises.
At present, energy enterprises are either directly state owned, or are in the form of a joint-stock
company. Since 1999, the Government has been creating business units from some of the
power generation and distribution subsidiaries, with ownership rights vested directly in the State
Property  Committee  on  behalf  of  the  Government  but  with  business  management
responsibilities assigned to Barki Tajik. The Government has begun restructuring Barki Tajik as
part of its plan to eventually privatize it. Under ADB TA (footnote 3), the Government prepared
time-bound action plans to corporatize and commercialize key agencies in the energy sector,
namely Barki Tajik (Appendix 2), Tajikkommunservice, and Naftrason.  A corporate charter for
Barki Tajik is to be adopted by December 2001. Elsewhere in the energy sector, greater
progress has been made, for example in privatizing state-owned gasoline stations.
3.  Program Loan
35. Under the PCIPL, a total of 30 policy reform measures were to be completed during
January 1999 to December 2000. Of these measures, 11 were required to be fulfilled as
conditions for the release of the second tranche. As of loan negotiations (6-8 November 2000),
the overall compliance of the policy reform measures was 14 out of 30 measures and for
second tranche conditions, 8 out of 11 conditions. Another three policy reform measures are
expected to be complied with by December 2000.
36. With regard to the second tranche release, two conditions relate to transport, one to
foreign investment, three to gas, and five to electricity (Appendix 3). To date, eight conditions
(one for foreign investment, two for gas, three for electricity, and two for transport) have been
met: (i) issuing amendments to the Foreign Investment Law, (ii) enactment of amendments to
the  Transport  Law,  (iii)  enactment  of  the  Energy  Law,  (iv)  implementation  of  a  quarterly
automatic tariff adjustment mechanism for electricity to take into account input cost factors that
are beyond the control of Barki Tajik, (v) achieving 75 percent cost recovery for electricity supply
to industry and agriculture, (vi) taking measures to ensure that Tajikkommunservice is able to
generate  sufficient  revenue  to  fully  recover  its  operational  costs,  (vii)  implementing  price
variations for gas supply to achieve cost recovery, and (viii) completing a comprehensive review
of the present road financing and cost recovery mechanisms to ensure sufficient revenue is
generated to recover the cost of operation and maintenance (O&M) of roads.
37. Based on the above, three second tranche conditions remain unfulfilled as of loan
negotiations: (i) achieving 50 percent cost recovery of electricity supply to residential consumers
(at present 23 percent); (ii) implementing measures to ensure that accounts receivable of Barki
Tajik will be at a level of 6 months or less of equivalent electricity sales (for 1999 it was 11
months);  and  (iii)  implementing  measures  to  ensure  that  accounts  receivable  of

a.  Cost Recovery for Residential and Industrial Supplies of Electricity
38. With the benefit of hindsight, the time targets set under the PCIPL for cost recovery were
not realistic. For example, full cost recovery was envisaged to be achieved over the two-year
program period 1999 and 2000. Even assuming no further local currency depreciation for the
rest of 2000, this would necessitate tariff increases in Tajik ruble terms over the 1998 levels by
5,900 percent for residential consumers and 289 percent for industry.  Such high tariff increase
requirements are partly an outcome of the significant devaluation of the Tajik ruble vis-à-vis the
US dollar (from TJR777/$1 in 1998 to TJR2,000 in August 2000) and partly due to the low tariff
base in 1998, and are just not feasible in the two-year period originally envisaged.
39. The  Government  has  nevertheless  made  major  tariff  increases.  Over  the  period
1 January 1999 to 1 April 2000, residential tariffs were increased by 1,300 percent (in Tajik ruble
terms), thus achieving an average cost recovery of 23 percent, still below the 50 percent cost
recovery stipulated for the second tranche release and the 100 percent recovery required by the
end  of  the  program  period.  Increases  in  the  other  categories  have  also  been  significant
(157 percent), resulting in cost recoveries of 100 percent for agriculture (above the 75 percent
required for the second tranche release and meeting the 100 percent target required by the end
of the program period) and 66 percent for industry. The Government also implemented a
quarterly automatic tariff adjustment mechanism for electricity from 1 September 2000, taking
into  account  input  cost  factors  that  are  beyond  the  control  of  Barki  Tajik  (Supplementary
Appendix B). Despite having made these large tariff increases, the Government undertook a
further base tariff increase of 51 percent for industry on 1 November 2000 resulting in 75
percent cost recovery for industry, in line with the target for second tranche release.
40. Taking into account the current state of the economy, the major tariff increases already
made, the electricity consumers’ low ability to pay, and ADB’s experience in other transition
economies, the tariff increases required to achieve PCIPL cost recovery targets will require
more  time,  particularly  for  residential  consumers.  Realistic  targets  for  achieving  full  cost
recovery for industry and residential consumers would be as follows:  (i) 50 percent and 100
percent  cost  recovery  for  residential  consumers  in  December  2002  and  December  2004
respectively, and (ii) 100 percent cost recovery for industrial consumers in December 2001.
IMF has been consulted on these relaxed targets for cost recovery and has incorporated them
in the Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility for Tajikistan.
41. Accordingly, the Government will adopt a strategy whereby industrial and residential
tariffs will be gradually increased to achieve full cost recovery in accordance with the ESAP. In
formulating its strategy, the Government agreed to adhere to financial covenants for Barki Tajik
on  operating  ratio24  and  rate  of  return  on  net  fixed  assets25  that  would  facilitate  full  cost
recovery.  The Government agreed that, to protect poor and vulnerable groups from the impact

national poverty reduction strategy, currently under formulation, is developed.26 Accordingly,
there will be no real increase in tariff for the initial consumption of 150 kWh per month for
residential consumers.  The lifeline tariff targets mostly the poor whose low purchasing power

b.  Accounts Receivable for Electricity and Gas
42. Barki  Tajik  has  significant  accounts  receivable,  mainly  from  industrial  customers.
Although its accounts receivable decreased from 13 months of sales in 1998 to 11 months of
sales in 1999, it will not be able to achieve the second-tranche PCIPL target of 6 months of
sales in the short term. This is mainly because the Tajik Aluminum Smelter (TADAZ), the
Government-owned aluminum smelting company, which is one of the largest in the world and
accounts for more than half of the total accounts receivable, cannot clear all its arrears in a
short period. The decline in economic conditions has reduced industrial production and delayed
payments from the industrial sector. TADAZ accounts for 34 percent of the electricity consumed
and, up to early 1999, the facility was not producing enough to cover its costs and accumulated
substantial  arrears  in  payment.  However,  with  the  Government's  ongoing  restructuring  of

international prices for aluminum, TADAZ is expected to gradually increase its production and
profitability levels. Under the recently issued Government Resolution No. 70 of 11 February
2000, TADAZ was required to restructure its outstanding electricity arrears and to ensure full
payment hereafter. As a result of the policy dialogue, the Government and TADAZ agreed on a

million equivalent to Barki Tajik.28 In August 2000, TADAZ made two payments to Barki Tajik
totaling $3 million. TADAZ has also been making cash payments in full from January 2000 on

the ESAP.

during  winter.  Tajikkommunservice  has  commenced  implementation  of  a  computer-based
system to monitor residential customer information, produce invoices, and record collections

gas  consuming  enterprises  and  residential  consumers,  with  payment  of  their  debts  being
deferred up to 4 years. As a consequence, it will be difficult for Tajikkommunservice to comply in
the near term with the second-tranche condition of three months for accounts receivable.

4.  Capacity Building
46. Capacity building in Tajikistan needs to start from the basic levels of defining new

financial management, project management, and power plant O&M as key components for
capacity building and training. Under the proposed Project, Barki Tajik will acquire project
management and benefit monitoring and evaluation skills through on-the-job training with the

IV.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT
A.  Rationale
47. The power sector in Tajikistan has been severely affected by the disintegration of the
FSU in 1990. Since then, construction of new hydropower plants has been halted and the
maintenance of existing infrastructure neglected due to lack of funds.  As a result of the poor
economic situation of the country and damage caused by the civil war, the present condition of
power facilities is serious (paras. 6-7). In addition, with the increase in prices of gas and
petroleum imports, residential consumers have switched to electricity generated by hydropower

facilities. Without improvements in power supply, the living conditions, particularly of the poor,
will be miserable as they cannot afford alternative fuels. In addressing poverty reduction, the
project design pays special attention to (i) facilitating the creation of employment opportunities
and additional income for the poor in the project areas, and (ii) improving living standards by
rehabilitating basic infrastructure.
48. A reliable and efficient power infrastructure is an important basic requirement for the
macroeconomic stabilization and economic recovery efforts of the Government. As the power
system  is  predominantly  hydro-based,  the  actual  generation  and  supply  depend  on  the
hydrological situation as well as on the condition of power plants, which in general is well below
full capacity because of lack of funds for maintenance and spare parts.  Based on GDP
projections (para. 14), energy sales are estimated to increase by 2 percent per year up to 2002.
Given the urgent need to overcome the power supply constraints and increase the efficiency of
supplying and utilizing energy, priority is being given in the medium term to retrofitting and
rehabilitating existing power facilities, rather than adding new capacity. The Project will therefore
rehabilitate and reinforce high-priority power generation, transmission, and distribution facilities
in various parts of the country. Benefits from the Project accruing from 2003 onwards will be
timely as energy sales are expected to increase by 3 percent per year in 2003 and 2004, and by
about 5 percent per year thereafter.
49. Better electricity supply will considerably improve irrigation and drainage for agricultural
production, the mainstay of economic activities in the project areas. The availability of electricity
will also reduce constraints on the development of cottage and small industries, which have a
significant potential of increasing employment and raising incomes. Better energy supply will
also have considerable benefits for the health of the population, particularly the poor.  Drinking
water supply and household electrical appliances such as cooking stoves and electric heaters
depend on electricity; when it is not available, people, mostly women and children, have to walk
far to fetch water and work hard to collect fuelwood. The availability of electricity will improve
drainage of farmland thus reducing the risk of malaria, allow the use of piped water for cooking
and drinking, and improve services at hospitals, health centers, and schools.
B. Objectives and Scope
50. The objectives of the Project are to (i) improve the peoples' quality of life, particularly the
poor,  and  support  poverty  reduction  through  increased  availability  of  electricity;  and
(ii) assist in the postconflict economic recovery of Tajikistan. This will be achieved by increasing
the availability and reliability of power supply in an environment-friendly manner, through the
rehabilitation of existing generation, transmission, and distribution facilities developed during the
FSU era.
51. The  project  components  were  selected  to  provide  a  reliable  and  efficient  power
infrastructure to improve the quality of life of the people, support poverty reduction, and assist in
the  economic  recovery  of  Tajikistan  (Supplementary  Appendix  C).  The  Project  has  five

C. Technical Justification
1.  Part A: Rehabilitation and Power Supply Improvement in Poor Areas in
Khatlon Region
52. In addition to the general degradation of power generation, transmission, and distribution
facilities  because  of  inadequate  maintenance,  supply  of  electricity  in  Khatlon  Region  has
suffered considerably from consequences of the civil war from 1992-1996. The region covers
most of the area south of Dushanbe, with a population of more than 2 million. Of 330,000
households in the region, about 24,000 households were cut off from power supply due to the
destruction of the local distribution system during the civil war. No substantial repair work has
taken place since, and in some areas households have managed to reestablish supply with
substandard lines and connections that are often unsafe. Such practices have increased line
losses significantly and overloaded distribution transformers.
53. The Project will rehabilitate about 230 km of medium voltage lines, 415 km of low
voltage lines, and 107 substations that supply these households. The substation rehabilitation

16
consists mainly of increasing the capacity of existing transformers that are overloaded, thus
reducing  transmission  losses  and  improving  reliability  of  electricity  supply.  In  addition,  the
households will be provided with consumer meters to encourage more efficient consumption, as
consumers would pay for actual electricity consumption rather than the current system based on
the number of rooms per household.
54. The collective farm, Sovhoz 2, covering 2,500 hectares in Bishkent District of Khatlon
Region is of particular importance as it is in an agricultural district providing employment to
10,000 people. Due to lack of electricity supply to the drainage pumping station, the land cannot
be adequately drained to allow for cultivation and malaria is common in the area. Lack of proper
drainage has raised the salinity of the land, making it nonarable, and increasing the salinity of
drinking water, making it unsafe for human consumption.  The rehabilitation of the associated
substation will provide power to the pumping station.
55. In addition, the Project will increase supply of electricity, especially in winter, in the
region by rehabilitating the 15 MW CHPP, which has not been operating for about eight years
due to lack of funds to procure spare parts. The Project will support the reconditioning of
generators,  replacement  of  auxiliary  equipment,  addition  of  a  new  110  kV  circuit  breaker,
refurbishment of the lubrication and cooling system, realignment of turbines, modernization of
the governing and control system, and reconditioning of intake gate and penstocks. These
measures will allow CHPP's plant life to be extended for least another 10 years and generation
of 36 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity per annum.
56. The efficiency of electricity supply operations in Khatlon Region has been severely
reduced by the lack of an adequate telecommunication system. The Project will improve the
telecommunication system by providing new ultra high frequency and very high frequency radio
equipment (covering 94 channels and 20 stations), and installing a new digital power line carrier
system including data acquisition connected with the dispatch center in Dushanbe.
2. Part B: Rehabilitation of NHPP and Associated Transmission Facilities
57. Given its size, the 3,000 MW NHPP plays a predominant role throughout the year in
Tajikistan's power supply. The Project will cover critical rehabilitation measures. The main
concern at present is stability of the 220 kV high voltage switchyard, where large sinkholes
caused by deteriorating subsoil conditions have appeared in 25 percent of the switchyard area.
While Barki Tajik is undertaking some remedial measures, the Project aims at providing a
reliable long-term solution to stabilize the foundations in the affected area. If the affected part of
the 220 kV switchyard were to collapse, two transmission lines would be disconnected resulting
in serious disruption in power supply in the south system including Dushanbe. In addition, the
27-year  old  circuit  breakers  need  to  be  replaced  with  new  circuit  breakers  that  are  more
compact and efficient, thus reducing the loading on the foundations. New protection relays are
included for all circuits, together with new voltage transformers and capacitor couplers for the
500 kV switchyard.
58. In the Soviet era, stability of the NHPP dam, which is the largest rock-filled dam in the
world, was analyzed on a regular basis. Dam monitoring is essential for safety but at present,
Barki Tajik cannot monitor the dam properly due to lack of equipment and technology. The
Project will include computer hardware, software, and training for the dam monitoring system.
The tailrace water head at NHPP is six meters higher than the design head, due to sediments
deposited downstream from the powerhouse. Under the Project, dredging of the tailrace section
of the river will increase power generation by 320 GWh per year.

17
59. A significant portion of electricity supplied in Tajikistan is delivered through 500 kV and
220 kV substations at Regar, in addition to the main electricity exchange with Uzbekistan via the
Central Asia grid. The rehabilitation of these substations will improve the grid’s efficiency and
reliability of power supply. This entails replacement of all seven 500 kV and eighteen 220 kV
circuit breakers, 500 kV capacitor couplers and voltage transformers, and protective relays.
3. Part C: Improvement of Power Supply Reliability in Dushanbe Region
60. The following measures are needed to improve power supply reliability in the Dushanbe
region, which has one million people: (i) increase the 220/110 kV transformer capacity at the
Novaya and Djangal substations, which currently have two transformers of 125 million volt-
amperes each, by an additional transformer at each substation; and (ii) replace the 220 kV and
110 kV bulk oil circuit breakers, which are 30 years old, at the two substations. The two
substations are the main supply points to the Dushanbe region and supply about 9 GWh daily.
The existing transformers are overloaded, and with no spares available in stock, a transformer
outage would significantly reduce power supply for at least a month. The failure of circuit
breakers would also result in interruptions or reductions in power supply to the Dushanbe
region.
4. Part D: Bulk Metering of Power Supply
61. About 500 electronic high-voltage meters will be installed at power plants and
high-voltage  substations  to  accurately  measure  electricity  exports  and  imports,  electricity
generated and sent-out, and the amount of electricity exchanged among Barki Tajik’s regional
distribution networks. The existing meters are old, and their accuracy is doubtful. The new
export-import meters will help resolve disputes over payment for electricity transfers, and will
allow accurate computation of power losses, thus benefiting consumers in the long run.
62. The  meters  at  the  boundaries  of  regional  distribution  networks  will  allow  accurate
measurement  of  power  transfers  between  supply  companies,  and  identification  of  losses.
Consumers will benefit from such measures to reduce losses. The meters will also allow load
profiles to be monitored thus enabling proper planning of electricity dispatch, and in future will
permit the automatic collection of data (when the communication system is put in place).
5.  Part E: Consulting Services
63. Approximately  216  person-months  of  consulting  services  will  be  needed  for  project

were grossly undervalued in Barki Tajik’s books, with a total of only $96 million against a gross
replacement  value  estimated  at  about  $3.75  billion.  As  a  result,  tariffs  failed  to  ensure
appropriate capital cost recovery. Barki Tajik’s accounts receivable have been a major problem
with a gross total at the end of 1999 of $67 million, or a net total of $46.8 million after deducting
provision for bad debts; this is the equivalent of 11.4 months of gross billings (paras. 42 to 44).
Retained earnings are minimal in Barki Tajik’s balance sheets as all operating surpluses are
transferred to the Government.
4. Financial Projections
82. A  major  part  of  ADB’s  policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  has  been  devoted  to
improving Barki Tajik’s financial performance. A comprehensive approach has been developed
in the ESAP that involves (i) improving operational efficiency and reducing losses, (ii) improving
the financial management system and accounting standards, and (iii) adjusting the level and
structure of tariffs.
83. Barki  Tajik’s  financial  projections  are  based  on  agreements  reached  with  the
Government to implement financial reforms that include the following: (i) Barki Tajik will adopt a
debt service covenant of at least 1.3 times; (ii) the Government will undertake all necessary
actions, including base tariff increases and implementation of tariff adjustments arising from the
quarterly automatic tariff adjustment mechanism, to ensure that Barki Tajik's operating ratio will
be below 90 percent from 2002 on, and Barki Tajik will generate a rate of return of 6 percent on
net fixed assets from the end of 2005 on; and (iii) Barki Tajik will reduce accounts receivable to
the equivalent of six months of billings by December 2001 and three months of billings by
December 2002.
84. With  the  implementation  of  these  measures,  Barki  Tajik’s  financial  performance  is
expected to gradually improve (Appendix 7 and Table 6). The financial projections assume
annual tariff increases in dollar terms of 22 percent in 2000, 25 percent between 2001 and
2005, and 10 percent thereafter. Such increases are realistic given the low tariff level and the

percent by 2003. After generating a negative return on net fixed assets during 2000 and
breaking even in 2001, Barki Tajik is expected to yield a rate of return of 6.7 percent by 2005.

H.  Environmental and Social Measures
1. Environmental Impacts
85. The Project is not expected to have any major adverse impact on the environment. It
consists entirely of rehabilitation of existing structures and facilities. The rehabilitation includes
replacing switchgear and transformers at existing substations, rehabilitating existing hydropower
plant components, and retrofitting new components to existing equipment. The Project has been
classified as Category B in ADB’s environmental classification system. An initial environmental
examination  was  undertaken  according  to  ADB’s  guidelines  at  the  feasibility  study  stage
(Appendix 8).
86. During construction, there could be air pollution and noise caused by trucks and other
vehicles for transport of materials and use of machines at sites. However, due to (i) the limited
scope and duration of construction, (ii) the type of materials to be transported, and (iii) the fact
that  measures  in  NHPP  take  place  outside  inhabited  areas,  no  negative  impact  requiring
specific mitigation measures will occur. An estimated 0.5-1.0 million cubic meters of material will
have to be excavated from the NHPP dam tailrace. An uninhabited unlevel area of about
7 hectares has been identified near the construction site as appropriate for depositing the
excavated material. The land belongs to the local government and Barki Tajik has obtained
authorization to use the excavated material to fill the uneven pockets. The material to be
excavated will not present any environmental risk and consists of rocks and sediments. Positive
environmental impacts from this are expected since tree cover can be established once the
filled area is leveled. The Project requires replacement of about 500 tons of transformer oil that
does not contain any poly-chlorine-biphenyl, which would be hazardous to health and the
environment. During replacement of transformers, this oil will be filtered and recycled for use as
fuel by Barki Tajik. The Government and Barki Tajik have agreed to remove and dispose of all
hazardous  waste  materials  associated  with  the  Project,  in  a  safe  and  environmentally
responsible manner.

25
2. Social Aspects
87. Under the project preparatory TA (footnote 4), an initial social assessment was carried
out  and  a  summary  of  the  assessment  was  prepared  according  to  the  ADB  guidelines
(Appendix 9). This assessment has shown that the risk of negative socioeconomic impacts is
small or nonexistent. None of the components identified will require any resettlement, and no
additional land is required except for the 7 hectares near NHPP. The improvement of energy
supply in the project areas will substantially improve the well-being of the people.
88. Electricity supply is a prerequisite for improving the economic situation and quality of life
in the project areas, as it is required for agriculture (irrigation and drainage), drinking water
supply, health, education, industry, and small-scale enterprises. Adequate energy supply will
remove an important obstacle to investments, and facilitate operation of private enterprises.
Agriculture  will  benefit  due  to  improved  irrigation  and  drainage.  Direct  and  indirect  health
benefits include (i) improved drainage that will reduce the risks from malaria, and saline water in
farmland and water table, (ii) improved water supply through use of electric pumps, and (iii)
ability to boil water efficiently thus reducing risks from unsafe water. Provision of lighting and
heating in schools will improve the education facilities and increase school enrolment.
3.  Gender and Development
89. Based on UNDP's gender-related development index, which fell from 0.57 in 1995 to
0.53 in 1998, the relative position of women has deteriorated. Women are more likely to be
unemployed than men: the unemployment rates are 28.8 percent for women and 25.3 percent
for  men.38  Women’s  wages  average  only  $2  per  month  as  compared  with  men’s  wages
averaging $6 per month. Women spend an average of 6.3 hours per day of unpaid work
(cooking, working on private plots, cleaning, laundry, etc.) compared to 3.3 hours by men. The
war has left an estimated 26,000 widows and 55,000 orphans who are even more severely
affected.
90. Women and children disproportionately bear the burden of using alternative fuels to
augment the lack of reliable electricity supply. Such use has economic, time, labor, health, and
social impacts. A one-month supply of fuelwood takes up to 15 days to gather. Work on cow
dung briquettes takes at least one hour per day per household during the summer to prepare
the  required  supply  for  winter.  The  use  of  these  energy  sources,  typically  for  cooking  in
unventilated  rooms,  constitutes  health  hazards  for  women  and  children,  who  spend
approximately five hours per day in such rooms. Prior to independence, piped water had been
provided to households. However, pumping from reservoirs and deep-wells has been restricted
because  of  the  current  irregular  electricity  supply.  Women  and  children  in  particular  fetch
drinking water which takes substantial amount of time, as they need to walk up to 15 km to
water sources. Due to transportation and storage, water obtained is often contaminated, and is
frequently not boiled due to scarcity of electricity. Consequently, the Project will have significant
positive impacts on poor women and children, particularly in Khatlon Region, in better health, a
reduced burden of household chores, and increased time for economic activities.
4. Poverty Reduction and Improving the Quality of Life of the Poor
91. The serious energy shortage, particularly in rural areas and mainly during winter, has
been  identified  by  the  Government,  households,  community  development  organizations,
nongovernment organizations, and international aid agencies as one of the most important

challenges to reducing poverty and improving the quality of life of the poor. Unless addressed,
Tajikistan will have difficulty resuming economic growth; increasing agricultural and industrial
productivity; generating employment; increasing incomes; and meeting basic needs such as
heating, safe water, and social services. Restoration and improvement of electricity supply is a
prerequisite for reducing poverty, improving quality of life, and sustaining economic growth.
92. Participatory rural assessments conducted during project preparation39 confirmed high
levels of poverty, particularly in rural areas. Formal employment is low, and, where available,
consists mostly of civil service employment where salaries are often several months late; or
seasonal employment in collective farms paying TJR2,000 ($1) per month during spring and
TJR10,000  ($5)  per  month  during  summer.  Formal  employment  for  women  is  even  less
available.  Women  spend  more  time  than  men  at  home  doing  unpaid  work.  Households
supplement their incomes through home plots, milk production, livestock, and small-scale retail
activities. In most households visited, these activities constituted the main source of income.
Most  income  is  received  during  summer  and  fall  harvest  season,  but  most  expenses  are
incurred during winter and spring, mainly for heating and clothing. Poor households receive
humanitarian aid from donor agencies through the local government, consisting of 5 liters of
cooking oil and/or 10 kilos of flour supplied every 3-6 months.
93. In the project areas, households report that electricity is available intermittently for most
of the year except during the winter (December to March), when electricity is available only for
2-4 hours a day. Because of lack of electricity, people have shifted to alternative sources of fuel.
Households spend as much as TJR25,000 (including time and cost) for fuelwood during winter
months, and where fuelwood is scarce, animal dung is used exclusively, averaging 1,500
briquettes during the winter and 300 briquettes during the rest of the year, which is valued at
TJR15,000 mainly for labor cost. Diesel is primarily used for lighting and igniting fuelwood or
animal dung, and its cost can reach TJR18,000 during winter months. Field visits confirmed that
the Project would have substantial impacts on reduction of poverty and improving the quality of
life of the poor through provision of cheaper and reliable electricity supply (valued at a lifeline
tariff of $0.003/kWh against alternative fuel costs of about $0.032/kWh) and freeing up time
used for gathering and using alternative fuels for generating additional income (e.g., working on
home plots, bread making, and sewing). In addition, the scarcity of electricity has health, social
and gender impacts (para. 90).
94. The large agricultural base, which is dependent on irrigation, has suffered from lack of
pumping facilities. As a result, farm yield has dropped to 20-25 percent of levels when Tajikistan
was part of the FSU. The provision of reliable electricity supply through the Project will reduce
poverty by increasing farming activity and providing employment opportunities to the poor in
particular.  The  provision  of  education  and  health  services  to  the  population  is  similarly
hampered by lack of electricity, thus reducing the quality of life of the poor in particular. Schools
are closed for two months during winter due to inadequate electricity for heating. This forces
schools to operate for extended hours during summer. School enrolment has dropped because
poor children, lacking warm clothes and shoes, do not attend school during the rest of winter.
Hospitals also lack heating, and delivery of services is greatly hampered by lack of electricity
supply. In particular, crucial medicines and vaccines cannot be properly stored at controlled
conditions. Hospitals that remain operational are in urban administrative centers, resulting in
high transportation costs and long travel time leading to even higher expenses for the poor who
live far from the centers. The Project will improve people's quality of life (especially for the poor)
by providing reliable and adequate electricity supply to schools and hospitals.

V. PROJECT JUSTIFICATION
A.  Financial and Economic Analyses
1.  Least Cost Analysis
98. During  the  feasibility  study  (footnote  4),  a  large  number  of  potential  alternatives,
including a do-nothing option, and their costs have been analyzed. For example, dredging of the
NHPP tailrace was compared with four options: (i) import of an additional 320 GWh of energy,
(ii) build a new hydro or diesel power plant providing 320 GWh, (iii) increase turbine efficiency
with new runners, and (iv) do nothing. In a similar manner, least cost options were examined for
other project-components, with more than 25 options considered in all. This analysis confirmed
that all project components are part of the least cost plan for power development in Tajikistan.
2.  Financial Analysis
99. Financial analysis for the Project from the perspective of Barki Tajik is based on capital
costs of $52.9 million—base costs plus physical contingencies, assuming an economic life of 15
years—5  years  for  construction  and  10  years  for  operation41  (Appendix  10).  Incremental
benefits of the Project are based on a "with project" and "without project" comparison and
include the incremental energy generated, improved reliability of power supply, and avoided
electricity losses.42 In particular, such incremental benefits are expected to be gained from (i)
increased power generation and supply reliability in Khatlon Region due to improved voltage
and uninterrupted electricity supply, avoided technical losses, and reduction of substandard
inefficient  connections;  (ii)  increased  power  generation  and  supply  reliability  through  the
rehabilitation of NHPP; and (iii) increased power supply reliability and transmission efficiency
through the rehabilitation of the Novaya and Djangal substations. These incremental benefits
are measured in billed electricity sales estimated at about 7.6 TWh during the period of analysis,
and valued at average revenue as per financial projections for Barki Tajik (but at constant year
2000 prices). On this basis, and after allowance for adequate O&M costs and income tax, the
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for the Project is 7.7 percent. The weighted average cost
of  project  capital  has  not  been  determined,  because  the  uncertain  economic  conditions
prevailing in Tajikistan do not allow determination of an indicative set of interest rates and rates
of return. However, the FIRR level indicates that the Project is financially viable in comparison
with the onlending rate to Barki Tajik. The results of sensitivity analysis, which are summarized
in Table 7, show that the Project remains financially viable with changes in key assumptions.

3. Economic Analysis
100. The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) has also been estimated comparing the

maintained for the economic analysis. In addition, for the economic analysis, (i) capital and

been excluded. Total electricity demand has been divided into incremental and nonincremental

exchange rate (TJR2,000 = $1). Nontradable commodities are valued at shadow price using a

4. Project Beneficiaries and Impact on Poverty
102. The rehabilitation of NHPP, CHPP, and transmission and distribution systems will benefit
the people in Tajikistan directly (about 1 million people or 172,000 households) and indirectly.
The reduced electricity losses and inefficiencies in direct utilization for household activities will
make more electricity available and improve the well-being of the population in the project
areas,  in  particular  during  winter.  The  difference  between  the  financial  and  economic  net
present values, and consequent gains and losses for different stakeholders, provide the basis
for considering the impact of the Project on the poor. For the poverty impact assessment, the
project beneficiaries are divided into three groups: consumers, Government economy, and
labor. The net economic benefits by group are distributed between poor and nonpoor. The
increased, more efficient, and reliable electricity supply resulting from the Project will benefit the
poor directly and indirectly. Net economic benefits accruing to the poor are estimated at about
$27 million (Appendix 12).  The poverty impact ratio, which expresses the proportion of net
economic benefits of the Project accruing to the poor, is estimated at 57 percent. This is

30
conservative as some indirect economic and social benefits are not considered. Hence, a
substantial portion of the project benefits will go to the poor and the Project can achieve its
primary objective of poverty reduction.
103. The  participatory  rural  assessments  (footnote  39)  confirmed  that  the  Project  would
reduce poverty. The project areas are characterized by high levels of poverty and are largely
rural. Due to climatic conditions, electricity is a basic need for heat, cooking, and irrigation water
in the project areas. The Project will also support improvement of other essential services such
as drinking water, education, and health. Adequate and reliable electricity will help generate
jobs through (i) economic development, and (ii) reduction of time spent obtaining and using
energy alternatives for productive activities. This will have significant impact on vulnerable
groups, particularly women and children.
104. Part A of the Project will have the greatest impact on the poor because it will improve
power supply for approximately 24,000 households comprised mostly of civil war returnees in
Khatlon Region. Field visits confirmed that returnees are among the poorest segment of society.
The collective farm Sovhoz 2 in the war-affected Bishkent District is of particular importance for
agricultural  production  (para.  54).  The  substation  rehabilitation  will  provide  power  to  the
pumping station, which will considerably improve conditions for agricultural production in the
district and reduce constraints on the development of small industries.
105. Electricity is required for economic growth and higher incomes, but it cannot be supplied
at the current low prices on a sustainable basis. The prevalent extreme levels of poverty affect
the ability of a significant portion of the population to pay higher electricity prices. If Barki Tajik is
unable to collect its bills, the power system will eventually collapse, making the poor even
worse-off.  The  Government  has  studied  several  possibilities  of  introducing  social  safety
measures to subsidize electricity for the poorest segment of the population (Appendix 13).
During the policy dialogue, the Government has agreed that in the medium term, there will be
no real increases in the tariff for an initial household consumption of 150 kWh per month.
A study of alternative fuel costs paid by poor households shows that the current tariff of
TJR5/kWh  to  be  applied  to  this  lifeline  consumption  is  affordable.  As  83  percent  of  the
population  live  below  the  poverty  line,  such  an  arrangement  is  considered  justified.  The
Government also proposes to use the interest margin arising from relending the loan from ADB
and cofinancing from the Swiss Government to Barki Tajik to fund the subsidy for the lifeline
tariff. If required, the Government will make up for any shortfall in the subsidy to Barki Tajik.
Under the ESAP, by January 2002, the Government is to provide proposals, acceptable to ADB,
for a safety net to protect the poor and vulnerable groups adequately with regard to impact of
tariff increases in the long term. Measures to be considered include changes to the tariff
structure for residential consumers, and the provision of a well targeted cash subsidy scheme to
the poor and vulnerable groups.
B.  Environment
106. The  Project  will  have  considerable  environmental  benefits,  mainly  through  reducing
losses in energy production at NHPP; eliminating the risk of NHPP's switchyard collapsing
which could lead to oil from the transformers contaminating the Vaksh River; improving dam
safety at NHPP; reducing electricity losses in the distribution system in Khatlon Region; and
reducing  pressure  on  alternative  sources  of  energy,  mainly  fuelwood43  and  other  biomass
resources.

C. Social Dimensions
107. The risk of negative socioeconomic impacts from the Project is small or nonexistent.
Since the Project focuses only on rehabilitation of existing facilities, none of the components will
require any resettlement. About 7 hectares of uninhabited land is required as a dumping ground
for rocks and sediments from the dredging of Vaksh River and Barki Tajik has already received
the  local  government's  approval  to  use  this  land  at  no  cost  (para.  86).  The  Project  will
substantially improve the social well-being of about 172,000 households, most of which are
poor. Given the climate in the project areas, electricity is a basic need for heat, cooking, and
pumping of safe drinking water. The Project will also support the improvement of essential
services such as irrigation and drainage, education, and health; facilitate direct employment;
and help generate jobs through induced economic development and by releasing time spent
searching  for  and  using  energy  alternatives  for  more  productive  activities.  This  will  have
significant impacts on vulnerable groups, particularly women and children.
D. Risks
108. Risks affecting the Project may be divided into two broad categories. Short- to medium-
term risks are associated with implementation and the achievement of immediate output. The
long-term strategic risks relate to the overall impact and sustainability of improvements brought
about by the Project. The former risks are related to availability of local funds, timeliness in
project implementation, and adequate project management. The Government has assured ADB
that the Project is given top priority for the economic development of Tajikistan, the necessary
funds will be made available in a timely manner, and adequate measures will be taken to
improve Barki Tajik’s financial situation. Given that this is ADB’s first power project in Tajikistan,
problems could be encountered in its implementation because of Barki Tajik's unfamiliarity  with
policies and practices of multilateral financing institutions. This risk will be mitigated through the
provision of (i) adequate and continued implementation consulting services; (ii) an adequate
time period to complete the Project, taking into account ADB's experience in other transition
economies; and (iii) regular training by ADB and the project implementation consultants for PIU
and  Barki  Tajik  staff  in  matters  related  to  procurement,  project  management,  social  and
environmental  issues,  benefit  monitoring,  and  loan  disbursement.  Adequate  project
management will also be ensured through ADB approval for key positions in the PIU.
109. In the long term, the risks associated with the sustainability of project benefits are related
to (i) the political stability in Tajikistan, (ii) the Government's commitment to energy sector

C. Potential Poverty Reduction Impacts
6. Participatory development exercises confirm high levels of poverty, particularly in rural
areas.  Formal  employment  is  low,  and  where  available,  consists  mostly  of  civil  service
employment where salaries are often several months in arrears; or seasonal employment in
collective farms paying TJR2,000 per month during spring and TJR10,000 during summer.
Women have lower levels of formal employment than men. Women spend more time at home
doing unpaid work. Households supplement their incomes through working on home plots, milk
production, livestock, and small-scale retail. In most households visited, these constituted the
main  source  of  income.  Poor  households  receive  from  donor  agencies  through  the  local
government humanitarian aid consisting of 5 liters of cooking oil and/or 10 kilos of flour supplied
every 3-6 months. Most income is received during summer and fall, coinciding with harvests, but
most expenses are incurred during winter and spring, mainly for heating and clothing.
7. Before independence in 1991, electricity supply had been reliable. But since then, the
provision of electricity has deteriorated sharply. Households confirm that electricity is available
intermittently for most of the year except during the winter months (December to March) when
electricity is only available for 2-4 hours a day. Because of lack of electricity, people have
increased  their  reliance  on  alternative  sources  of  fuel.  The  most  typical  alternatives  are
fuelwood, agricultural waste, animal dung, and diesel. Three to five cubic meters of fuelwood
and agricultural waste are required per month during winter, and 1-2 cubic meters during
summer months. At a market value of TJR5,000 per cubic meter, households spend as much as
TJR25,000 (including time and cost) on fuel during winter months. Where fuelwood is scarce,
animal dung is used intensively, averaging 1,500 briquettes per household during winter months
and 300 briquettes during rest of the year, valued at TJR15,000 mainly for labor cost. Diesel is
primarily  used  for  lighting  and  igniting  fuelwood  or  animal  dung.  Interviews  with  some
households show that the cost for using diesel for illumination can reach TJR18,000 during
winter when electricity is not available. Other alternatives such as kerosene, coal, and liquefied
petroleum gas, though available, are used in limited quantities due to prohibitive costs. Further,
the sources of these fuels are typically several kilometers from villages, and households do not
store these fuels due to indoor safety considerations.
8. Field visits supported the view that the provision of electricity will have substantial impact
on reduction of poverty and improving the living conditions of the poor. In Tajikistan, as in other
Central Asian countries, electricity provision has clear links with the level of poverty. Due to
harsh winters, heat is a basic need. For three decades the Tajik people had reliable, year-round
electricity, but are now often deprived of it.
9. Alternative fuels are expensive and entail high costs in time, labor, health, social and
gender impacts. Fuelwood, agricultural waste, and biomass gathering takes 15 days for one
month of use. Households spend one hour daily each summer making cow dung briquettes to
generate the required supply for winter. Gathering and preparing these energy sources is done
primarily by women and children. The use of these energy sources, typically for cooking in
unventilated rooms, is a health hazard for women and children who spend approximately five
hours per day in these cooking rooms. During focus group discussions, participants ranked
electricity as the best form of energy based on availability, convenience, affordability, time,
indoor safety, environmental considerations, and storage requirements. This is often followed by
fuelwood, agricultural wastes, animal dung, and diesel.
